Allow dots in module filenames.

This allows config files like `/config/foo.bar.js` to be read in, instead of being ignored.  It's likely that the previous regex was intended to capture everything up to the final `.` as the filename, it just wasn't working quite as expected.  Note that for modules that derive their identity from the filename, it's up to the hook that loads the module to deal with dots.  For example, sails-hook-orm will fail to lift with a helpful error if you try to name a file `api/models/Foo.bar.js`.
Skip compatibility checks in `sails upgrade` when running in `reportOnly` mode

Add pass-through __ and i18n functions when i18n hook de-activates itself.

As of https://github.com/balderdashy/sails/commit/e20d2e2d0a2bdd46d94425a828350be39fc3eca4, i18n deactivates itself if there are no locales configured, to avoid unexpected warnings when using Sails programmatically.  But it means that using __ will crash an app that upgrades from v0.12, where `locales` had a default.  This commit keeps i18n safe for programmatic use while avoiding these crashes (but logs a warning).

NODE_ENV only has special meaning if it === 'production'

This replaces a "isUndefined or `==='development'`" check with `!=='production'`

If your NODE_ENV is set to "foobar", or "test", or "staging", or "prod", or "ANYTHING" other than `production`, we take that to mean that you're in development mode.  NODE_ENV is used strictly to check for the "effective production-ness".  For more flexibility, use `sails.config.environment`.  For example, you might want a particular staging environment to run with NODE_ENV=production, but a different staging server emulating a developer box to run _without_ NODE_ENV set.  Similarly, you  might want to run your tests with _and_ without NODE_ENV=production.

Fix issue where `find` blueprint crashes when to-one association isn't populated

Without the `_.isObject()`, the check passes if the record has a non-populated singular association, since it'll have the primary key as the value, but in the `subscribe` code it's looking for a full record, not an ID.  Technically we could mock up an object so that the subscription could go through, but since non-populated plural associations don't get subscribed to, it's more consistent to fix singular associations this way.

Tweak comment: When 'replace' blueprint action is able to use a transaction, it should use res.badRequest(err) instead of res.status(409).json(err).  (That way, behavior in this edge case remains configurable throughout Sails v1.  In future versions, we'll move towards additional blueprint config to solve this.  See https://github.com/balderdashy/sails/commit/518bae84f01d17eac84c96977e5ed0c3b6a98083#commitcomment-20917978 for some ideas)

Revert the changes from 6c25e89aa16b0dfa32869b1d25dcc488b793b09b, because the cost of status code stickiness in this case is greater than the benefits.  For future reference, the best way to solve this is probably to expose additional blueprint configuration.  For now, this can be solved using the approach documented here: https://github.com/balderdashy/sails/issues/3980#issuecomment-279345050  (i.e. run  'sails generate response badRequest', then pop that new file open and add a check for err.code==='E_UNIQUE' (and if so use 409 status code instead of 400).

Adjust the error 'name' used for the E_UNIQUE error negotiation in da92b0664faa10681352015b25ed14222bafad13 and f9d124102200f7ae458595374533366edd8fa65d

handle E_UNIQUE in replace blueprint action

The only time "replace" would encounter a uniqueness error is if there was concurrent logic running somewhere that was messing around with the database at the same time  (it could never occur due to duplicates in the array of new child ids because of [this](https://github.com/balderdashy/waterline/blob/7b3e5f3229a9caef4bdb6a5e3cdb4868d0717141/lib/waterline/utils/query/private/normalize-pk-value-or-values.js#L89-L91)).  Since we don't currently use transactions in blueprints (and because, in some cases e.g. xD/A or adapters that don't support `join`, we'll never be able to use transactions), we handle this with a 500 error for now (because in the database could be in an a intermediate state, and this endpoint doesn't attempt to rectify that).  In the future, in the case where this blueprint action was able to use a transaction, it should respond with a 409 instead (because any changes we made would have been rolled back automatically due to the failure).

negotiate uniqueness errors on add (e.g. from multicolumn indexes on the junction)

Better logic around getting/setting _middlewareType when binding functions

Setting _middlewareType in the `options` argument to `.bind()` is only supported for cases where it's not practical to set it directly on the function itself (like when the function is being created inline in the call to `.bind()` ).  So once it's been read, we remove it from the options so that it doesn't get merged in to the `req.options` dictionary that eventually winds up in the request handler.

Refactor security hook config

* Move CORS config into the main `configure()` method of the security hook, including deprecation notices, errors and transformation of options at the route level
* Update variable names in the CORS `.initialize()` method to be more clear (e.g. `routeCorsConfig` instead of `config.cors`, `sails.config.security.cors` instead of `globalCorsHeaderSettings`)
* Transform the Sails CORS options into the options expected by the CORS headers module _inside that module_, instead of in the hook, so that config properties (e.g. `allowOrigins`) are consistent throughout the hook and there's no confusing `.origin` settings.

- Reads only config files when reading config files from 'config/env/*' The 
previous implementation was reading any kind of file extension.
- Reads only config files when reading config files from 'config/env/**'. The 
previous implementation was reading any kind of file extension.
- Reads only config files when reading config files from 'config/local'. The
previous implementation was reading any kind of file extension, it was requiring
other files found in our projects, such as local.sample files.
- Reads only config files when reading config files from 'config/*'. The 
previous implementation was reading any kind of file extension, such as .md 
files

Merge pull request #3915 from luislobo/added-more-seconds-to-timeout-in-test

[patch] Change the test timeout to 10 seconds. It errored with just 4

Fixes express 4.x deprecated messages when using send(code, msg)

Since 4.x, send(code, msg) has been deprecated. The current way of sending a code and a message is res.status(code).send(msg). Also, sending just a status code should use sendStatus

Check http://expressjs.com/en/4x/api.html#res.send, http://expressjs.com/en/4x/api.html#res.status and http://expressjs.com/en/4x/api.html#res.sendStatus for more info

After humanizing env vars, just add them directly to the config obj returned by RC rather than merging

This is okay because the value of the config at that path is already set to the env var (albeit the stringified version before we humanize it), because in RC env vars override everything else, so there's nothing for us to merge into.  But before this commit, if you did `sails_security__cors__allowOrigins='["http://foo.com","http://bar.com"]' sails console`, it would humanize that value _and then merge it with the string value_ giving terrible, horrible, no good very bad results.  See https://runkit.com/sgress454/584764b15b8bbb00149c34e7

Change the test timeout to 10 seconds. It errored with just 4

Also, fixed typo

Handle legacy policy config, + tests

Migrating this by hand could be tedious for large config/policy.js files, and there's no chance of old/new configs colliding since the former uses a key->dictionary approach and the latter is strictly key->array.  So, we can transform the old to the new and log a warning that includes the transformed object for them to copy and paste, reducing the effort in upgrading to Sails 1.0 a bit.
No more view for `forbidden` response

Strip trailing slash from URL provided in `sails.config.session.url`

Trailing slashes have been known to cause issues with some hosted Redis providers.  See https://github.com/luin/ioredis/issues/74#issuecomment-112383346

Update EJS to v2.5.5

This remediates security issues detailed in https://snyk.io/vuln/npm:ejs:20161130 and https://snyk.io/vuln/npm:ejs:20161130-1

When disabling pubsub hook, delete it from `sails.hooks` rather than setting it to false

This is mainly to make the output nicer when inspecting the Sails object (with it set to `false`, you get a blank entry in the list of hooks), but it's also good in case someone does `_.isUndefined(sails.hooks.pubsub)` for some reason.  It's alright for the _sails.config.hooks.foo_ to be false, but `sails.hooks.foo` should either be a Hook object or `undefined`.

Update functionality of globals config

* The implicit default is `false` -- no globals at all
* If `sails.config.globals` is not `false`, it must be a dictionary such that:
  - If `sails.config.globals._` is not `false`, it must be an object
  - If `sails.config.globals.async` is not `false`, it must be an object
  - `sails.config.globals.models` must be a boolean
  - `sails.config.globals.sails` must be a boolean
* `sails.config.globals.services` still defaults to `true` if ``sails.config.globals` is a dictionary, because otherwise we have to talk about it explicitly and we're trying to phase services out.

Use _.clone() instead of _.cloneDeep() for config overrides.

This prevents configs used in lifting Sails programmatically from getting messed up -- for instance an instantiated Redis client passed directly into `sails.config.sockets.adapterOptions.pubClient`.

Replace all references to `sessionConfig` with `app.config.session` for clarity.

This avoids confusion as to where the `sails.config.session` object is actually being manipulated.  It seemed for instance like we could make the session store a private var in this code, but it was actually being directly attached to the config object which is directly passed in as options to the raw Express middleware.  It's still possible we could clone the initial `sails.config.session` at the beginning and make the _whole cloned thing_ a private var -- the aim being to not expose the adapter and store to the end user -- but we'll tackle that at another time.

Updates to RPS

* The former `publish` method is now officially private, and renamed to `_publishRPS`
* All formerly public RPS methods (e.g. `publishCreate`) are now private, with an underscore as a reminder
* Contexts are no more -- they were never documented, and thus underutilized.  RPS methods now all broadcast to the '*' subroom of an instance (e.g. `sails_model_user_123:*`), and continue to use the model identity as the event name.
* The public `subscribe` and `unsubscribe` methods now take an optional `room` argument, defaulting to the model identity.  This will be documented as `event` (see notes about `message` below)
* The former `message` method is now the public `publish` method, using `(records, event, data, req)` signature.  The `event` also doubles as the room name, for simplicity.  So end users can subscribe a socket to the `foo` event using `User.subscribe(req, userId, 'foo');`, publish using `User.publish(userId, foo, {})`, and listen on the client with `io.socket.on('foo', ...)`.

Remove `www` and `favicon` from the default middleware order, adding them after the express server is initialized instead.

In previous Sails versions (that used Express <4), the router was added as part of the middleware stack in sails.config.http.middleware.order, so we could just put these middleware after `router` in that list. In Express 4, the router is built in, so we have to wait until the server is fully initialized and then add the post-router middleware after.

Added check for res.headersSent before attempting to send a response due to the session middleware triggering its callback with an error.  Even though this is usually indicative of a timing issue in app-level code (where it attempts to respond more than once, simultaneous with a session store issue-- e.g. a hiccup in the redis connection), the process still should not crash, if possible.  Since recovery is possible here, and _some_ sort of response has obviously been sent, it's preferable to keep the process alive in this scenario.

Support PATCH for REST blueprints

Adds support for PATCH HTTP method to REST blueprints.

ROADMAP.md: Add CORS proposal to backlog

I'm not entirely familiar with the submission process. If you notice something missing, or the issue does not follow the guidelines completely, I'll submit a corrected version as soon as possible. 

===Summary===
Currently Sails CORS hooks are implemented in a way that differs a bit from the formal specification and can cause some undesired effects in certain enviroments. The primary cause are some blank headers set by Sails that should not be present as far as the aforementioned specification is concerned. While it doesn't matter in most cases, it may prevent other software that sits in from of the Node.js server from setting their own headers unless the CORS hook is disabled. In order to get a "sane" behavior, as well as minimizing the information one "attacker" may be able to obtain from a response, the removal of the blank headers is suggested in all cases but those explicitly required to be compliant with the present conventions regarding request processing. I.e., Sails method to clear CORS headers should effectively remove the headers themselves, not set them to '', and request processing should be terminated in case no matching origin for the request is found, instead of sending Access-Control-Allow-Origin: ''.


The proposal also suggests 2 new additions:
  The first one leverages the use of the "Vary" header to allow Sails CORS to work with some reverse proxys used for caching. Without that header, a reverse proxy as Varnish, may cache a single version of the response, allowing only a single origin to access the representation of the response. If two or more origins are allowed, then only the origin present in the first request is going to be cached, effectively denying the access from requests from any of the other hosts. If the request is not allowed, then no hosts will be allowed until the request expires from cache. 
- Higher security levels preventing the request from being processed such as those returning status codes 400, 500, etc. shouldn't be a real concern, as those won't be normally cached. 

 The second one would allow the usage of Access-Control-Allow-Origin: * in the response in case of public resources without access checks. This would allow caching of resources even when the Vary header is not supported. 

Both options would be disabled by default, and their usage would be completely optional.

==Required changes==
The changes described in the previous section affect core elements of Sails, and can not be implemented extending it. On top of that, they would require either changes in the test suite ( the first change in particular), or new tests to cover the new functionality (the second and third changes). 

The affected files, without any particular order would be:

===CORS hook===
- clear-headers.js => Replace the usage of "res.set" for "res.removeHeader"
- to-prepare-send-headers.js => Minor code changes

===Tests===
- test/integration/hook.cors_csrf.test.js => Modification of assertions of the headers from denied requests. Inclussion of new tests.

===Backend generator, from sails-generate-backend===
- templates/config/cors.js => Addition of the new configuration options, if considered relevant.

===Documentation===
Update the relevant information in the documentation, providing examples, if required.

I'd like to ask for forgiveness in case someone finds the present description "a bit rude". English is not my mother first language and I had trouble to phrase some of the contents in this proposal. It was in no way my intention to offend any of the contributors behind Sails, or to disrespect them or the project itself. I lack experience contributing to other open source projects and did it with the sole purpose of trying be of helpful in regards to the issue at hand.

refs #3608

Force async-ness in template rendering methods

There is a long-standing open bug in consolidate - https://github.com/tj/consolidate.js/issues/143 - which causes errors in the callback functions passed to rendering methods to propogate back into the try/catch contained in consolidate and cause the callback to be fired twice. Since this bug has been open in consolidate for over two years, not much hope should be held of having it resolved there.

As such, add protection in Sails against errors in the callback functions being caught inside consolidate and the callback fired twice by forcing the callback to be called asynchronously.

Ensure req._sails is always set

Certain parts of the codebase - in particular the built is response functions access req._sails to gain access to log functions. However, the setting of req._sails is currently bundled with the "request" hook, which contains potentially undesirable code - in particular around parsing req.params.all(), which can have a severe performance impact in certain situations - so may be disabled.

By setting `req._sails` by default on all requests we can ensure that the built in response helpers are usable indepenently of what intermediate hooks and middleware have loaded.

Make res.set() chainable

This fixes a bug which causes Sails to become unresponsive (or even
crash) when a message portraying an OPTIONS request for an undefined
route is emitted over the socket.io REST interface.

Steps to reproduce:

In a terminal:
$ sails new killme
$ cd killme
$ sails lift

In a browser's JS console (on localhost:1337):
> io.socket.request({method: 'options', url: '/anUndefinedRoute'});

The issue is a result of using Express' router with a constructed
response object which does not meet expectations set by Express.
For OPTIONS requests, Express' router enters a code path where send()
is called on the result of res.set() (see line 188 of lib/router/index.js
in Express v3.x). When/if set() is not chainable, we trigger an
infinite loop which brings Sails down.

The patch could have undesirable side effects if the value previously
returned from set() is used somewhere. I could not find any such
occurences in this repository. In any case, this should be considered
a quick-fix, since ideally, we should not use a third-party router at
all, to avoid similar issues (in other words, fix the TODO on line 46
in router/index.js).

The issue happens with Express v3.x, possibly not an issue in later
versions where the relevant code seems to have been subjected to
major refactorizations.

Fix grunt launching when it's a peer dep

There are times where someone may have grunt-cli installed as a peer
to sails. In those cases, the grunt-cli bin script isn't where we
thought it would be.

This patch uses a thin wrapper around grunt-cli, so we can exec it no
matter where it was actually installed. It just needs to be in the path
where require() can find it.

Fix crash when using sessionless requests over WebSockets.

When disabling sessions for individual requests, it's done by deleting
the session field from the request. (See
https://github.com/balderdashy/sails/issues/841).

Unfortunately, the REST-over-WebSocket code assumed that the session was
always there. This patch checks for the existence of req.session before
calling req.session.save.

Set CORS headers on CSRF denial responses, for easier debugging
Without this, a cross-domain POST with a bad token will get a CORS error in the browser, obscuring the fact that the problem is really a CSRF token mismatch.

Test inline policy in routes config.

Don't allow explicit routing to controller/action unless it's a custom action
Routes like "UserController.find" will no longer work unless you have a custom "find" action in your User controller.  To use the "find" blueprint, route to {"blueprint":"find", "model":"user"} or, if the path starts with /user/, just {"blueprint": "find"} will do.

Simplified CORS+CSRF handling
In CSRF hook, added /csrfToken route directly to sails.config.routes so that CORS hook will process it like every other route.  This also allowed simplification of the route handler--no need for more CORS checks since the CORS hook will handle it.
In CORS hook, removed all references to CSRF entirely; it's just another route now.  Also removed code related to sending 403 responses for socket requests on bad origins, since we're doing that for ALL requests now regardless of transport.
Skip same-origin requests in CORS catchall, but catch everything else even if no access control header was set

Only set headers if they'll have values
Prevents sending a header in the response with a value of "undefined"
Added "Access-Control-Allow-Credentials" to x-domain /csrfToken response
Expose original function being bound to route in router:bind event

Updated CSRF protection
CSRF check is always made now it protectionEnabled is on, but the token is only set if its from an approved origin (or is not cross-domain)

Added a CORS catchall route handler that denies requests from disallowed domains
Added a CORS preflight route handler that basically says yes to everything

Updated the way the router binding log works

Added _middlewareFn key and/or function names wherever possible in hooks

Added "log" option to controller action and policy functions
Now with sails lift --silly, you can see what is being bound to each route--no more mystery double log messages.
Added ability to add custom log message to router "bind" method, to make it easier to tell what's being bound.

Moved fs-extra to dependencies

Sails uses fs-extra. On production, my app now doesn't start because it's missing fs-extra. Example: `node_modules/sails/lib/router/res.js`

Output on my server:

```
islive@node01 ~/apps/fortress (master)
$ node app.js
{ [Error: Cannot find module 'fs-extra'] code: 'MODULE_NOT_FOUND' }
To run an app using `node app.js`, you usually need to have a version of `sails` installed in the same directory as your app.
To do that, run `npm install sails`

Alternatively, if you have sails installed globally (i.e. you did `npm install -g sails`), you can use `sails lift`.
When you run `sails lift`, your app will still use a local `./node_modules/sails` dependency if it exists,
but if it doesn't, the app will run with the global sails instead!
```

After installing fs-extra in node_modules everything worked just fine.

Send `locals` as second argument to `res.render`
This allows locals specified by the user to override `res.locals`, which, as a function, has some immutable properties like `name`.  Currently, we're merging all of the user-defined locals into `res.locals`, so those immutable properties are squashing some user-defined ones.

Tests for blueprint route options.
Use options.limit for blueprint route populate limit before falling back on DEFAULT_POPULATE_LIMIT

Make educated guesses about options when specifying a blueprint route in `config/routes.js`

If you have a model User and a route config `'/user': {blueprint: 'find', limit: 5}` it will automatically set the model option to `user` for you, and set all the associations options.  You can specify an `associations` option manually with an array of strings representing the keys that you'd like to populate, e.g. `['pets', 'children']`.

Added ability to configure default record limits for blueprints.

Use `sails.config.blueprints.defaultLimit` for general record limits.  This also serves as the default limit for populated associations.
Use `populate_limit` in your route config options to set the populate limit on a per-route basis.
Use `populate_[alias]_limit` in your route config options to set the populate limit for a particular association on a per-route basis (e.g. `populate_pets_limit: 10`)
Clone the options object before referencing it in enhancedFn so that it can't be overwritten later by other route configs.

Merge branch 'master' of https://github.com/balderdashy/sails

Regex routes!

Bind a regex path using:
"r|<regex string here>|<comma delimited param names here"

Regex string should not include delimiters or options.
e.g.
"r|/\d+/(\w+)|foo"
will match 123/abc and provide req.param('foo') == "abc"

Also added two new route options:
skipAssets (boolean): if TRUE, route will not match URLs that look like files (i.e. anything ending with a dot and a file extension)
skipRegex (RegExp/array): Regular expression (or array of regular expressions) to match URL against, and SKIP the specified middleware if it matches.  Used by skipAssets internally.

Add "introduce" call back to default publishCreate method.

Been a bit wishy-washy on this, but it just makes sense to have it in both places, even if it means it will usually be called twice.  If you override the "create" action and call "publishCreate", the expected behavior will be that watchers get introduced to the new model.  Similarly, if you use the blueprint "create" but override "publishCreate", I think you'd still expect watchers to be introduced, unless you're overriding publishCreate `explicitly` to suppress the introduction.  For that reason, an options parameter has been added to publishCreate that will allow you to suppress the introduction without overriding the whole method.

V0.10

publishCreate and publishDestroy no longer omit client from instance room subscriptions

The requesting socket shouldn't be told about the instance it has just created, but it should be subscribed to the new room. Similarly, when an instance is destroyed, the requesting socket shouldn't be told about it, but it should be unsubscribed from future room updates.

Socket interpreter's transactional session stuff now works like connect cookieParser/session -- automatically generates a session if one doesn't exist.  Accomplishes this by faking a cookie on the socket, newing up a session, and maintaining that session for the life of the socket.  At some point, a method needs to be figured out of associating a proper session instead-- maybe by sending a surrogate token back to the server on subsequent requests.  Alternatively, if sails.io.js client accomplishes full emulation of http cookies, the Connect middleware can just be used directly.  This would be optimal, I think.
Refactor session/sockets to afford more built-in support for socket upgrades which do not include cookies.

Waterline works in persistent and non-persistent mode-- tests will not pass multiple runs of persistent mode because multiple simultaneous waterline instances exist, causing a race condition where, since each instance is sharing the 'User' collection, the tests are writing on top of one another's auto-increment values on teardown.
Dirty db works in-memory
Removed the DirtyLocksmithAdapter.

Cleaned up, set up DirtyAdapter to use an in-memory autoincrement.  Adapters may use transactions, but the transaction adapter MUST have built-in auto-increment support (without having to write app-layer transactions).

Several bug fixes, plus added a patch to use in-memory auto-increment to determine insert order instead of a timestamp (also added node-micro dependency in case we want to go back later).  In either case, this makes DirtyLocksmith transactions single-node dependent, which is problmatic.  Instead, in production, you'd want to use a different adapter for transactions (anything with auto-increment built in).  However, on the waterline side, it would be better to ELIMINATE the dirtyLocksmith, use DirtyDb instead, but then remove the reliance within DirtyAdapter on transactions (use in-memory auto-increment).  Dirty is not supposed to be used in production anyways.  Then we would *not* use id, we would use some other obscure attribute like __transaction_insert_id and assign it the autoIncrement propeorty.

Added the ability to assign policies directly to accounts

Added more robust authentication system inspired by openstack's Keystone API.  Now supports dynamic account, role, and tenant policy mappings.  It does not come with built-in awareness of content ownership, but it can be easily emulated by using the default mapping for Policy objects-- controllers and route id parameters.  Currently Accounts cannot have Roles, and therefore cannot have Policies, which is innacurate.
